history.content: Took with Prof El Ghaoui in Spring 2017.  I would say it's not a must have, but I personally found it to be a useful reference.  He also provides free access to a "livebook" of the textbook, which is an interactive, shortened, online version. Sometimes the livebook is good enough, but I did refer to the actual textbook when I wanted more detail.  The Convex Optimization book by Stephen Boyd (Stanford Prof) is a useful reference for the second half of the course.

children.subject: Took it last semester with Calafiore, I imagine the class will be run somewhat similarly (except for the test format). I think the textbook is really good and a very good study resource. I think the class is doable without it, but I highly recommend getting it if you can. It's a great book in my opinion and does a good job of motivating a lot of the more abstract concepts you cover.

Can I ask if 127 is self study-able with the textbooks, since I'm not sure I'll be able to take it? Maybe I can just look through Stanford's EE364ab (which is Boyd's class on convex optimization at Stanford) instead?

Thanks in advance

I took it last semester too, just like Anon above me. I personally did not find it to be that good. I preferred to use two different textbooks for the 2 halves of the class. Strang's Linear Algebra for the review portion and Boyd's Convex Optimization for the rest. The former is a really good textbook that I personally think everyone should have anyways, and the second you can find online for free.

Since the head TA from last semester linked it for us last time, I don't think there should be an issue with linking it here again: https://web.stanford.edu/~boyd/cvxbook/bv_cvxbook.pdf

Both books I listed were recommendations made by the head TA last semester by the way. (Piazza post @56 of last semesters 127 page.)

history.content: For those who've taken this course, does EECS 127 rely heavily on the textbook (Optimization Models - El Ghaoui), or can I get away with just lecture notes? I'm trying to decide whether or not to buy the book (I know there's a PDF somewhere online, but I'd rather have a physical copy if it's important). Thanks.
history.subject: EECS 127 Textbook - Important?
